subtitle: Hello everyone, so as you all know if you've been following my videos or read my book
you'll know that the ability to remember dreams is crucial to any practice
of lucid dreaming or Astral projection... why? because the ability to recall
non-physical experiences is like a muscle that needs to be exercised
most people don't think they dream at all because they don't remember their dreams, but in reality
they dream every night they just don't remember them, or better said they don't bother to remember
them and it is absolutely possible and quite common to have astral projection experiences
but not even remember them; that's how atrophied our connection is to experiences during sleep, and
so in this episode I'm going to share with you a very powerful mantra that i've used for many years
which has helped me to remember my experiences in great detail upon waking up in the morning
I'll explain how to do the mantra, demonstrate it, and talk a little bit about the meaning behind it
again, this mantra was taught to me by my Gnostic teacher just like the mantra I showed you all for
Astral projection which is in the video called "My Easy Step-by-Step Method for Astral Projection"
it's on the screen now if you want to check that out; since i posted that video there's been a lot
of great feedback and people having successful lucid dreams and Astral projection experiences
with the mantra i shared on there - you can see just some of what people said they experienced
on the screen now... I'll also be sharing more astral projection mantras in future episodes so
be sure to be subscribed some of these screenshots come from our Astral Doorway Discord group
so if you'd like to join that just check out the link in the description below, and on that note
just a quick shout out to Michael, Jacob, Odysseus, Connor and Jaelyn who all joined this week... so to
give you an example from my own experience and really get you to understand just how
important the ability to remember experiences is, I've had several occasions where i just woke up
and didn't bother to think about what i dreamt or anything because i had such a busy day ahead of me
my mind was so focused on future events of the day instead of remembering to recall my dreams
and some days I've gone over six hours of focusing on the day's tasks and getting them done
when i finally and spontaneously remembered that I had a full-blown astral projection experience
when i was asleep six hours ago, and even though i was lucky enough to remember them
i could only recall parts of them because i waited too long... now i know that may be hard to understand
because you might say "but if you have an astral projection experience isn't it so mind-blowing and
make such a big impression on the mind that it's hard NOT to remember"?... well, yes, actually in
most cases that is true, and i do find that's the main reason most experiences are so
easy to remember, however, it can still happen where you just don't remember it especially if you don't
remember to recall any experiences when you first wake up, this may be even more of the case if you
had an experience during the first stages of your sleep rather than towards when you were
about to wake up, we can have experiences during any time of our sleep cycle, not just the REM stage,
so the first and main practice for anyone getting into all of this is to recall your dreams, it is
so important, now trust me it doesn't matter how much you think you don't dream or think
you can't recall them - it's seriously easy to start remembering them with just a few days of practice
and you'll see once you start remembering them for a few days it's so much easier to remember them
every morning afterwards, and not just one dream but you'll start to remember two, three, four and
even up to ten different, long, detailed dreams with all completely different scenes and narratives
that's not an exaggeration ~ like i just said this is simply a muscle that needs to be exercised and
it is completely possible to remember all of your experiences if that muscle is very strong.
I worked with a lady in her 80s some years ago and you know she was interested in Astral
projection and all of this and has read books by Lobsang Rampa when she was younger, but she
felt that she couldn't do any of it because she couldn't even recall her dreams and
hasn't remembered any in over 20 years, so like i'm telling you all now i told her you know "don't
worry it's fine you've just not been placing your intention to remember them" and so i gave her some
instructions and she started practicing every day and she told me she was struggling a bit at first
but i think it took about a week, she came up to me all excited and she finally remembered
a dream and she told me all the details about it and it was actually a very significant dream
related to a past partner who she hadn't seen for decades and it was related to her subconscious
emotions about him and her past with him and she continued to remember her dreams more and more and
it was very interesting to hear how each dream related to her past relationship with this man
and how each dream progressed emotionally as she continued to realize the kind of past emotions
that she was holding on to, and eventually she also dreamt about her recently passed away husband and
she started having all sorts of different friends from the past communicating to her through dreams
so i won't go too in-depth about that i've already spoken about how significant dreams are
and how they can help us to heal and learn more deeply about ourselves - but the point is you can
absolutely start to remember your dreams every morning in-detail and also eventually gain an
inner understanding of them too it's one thing to remember your dreams, and another thing to have the
inner intuitive understanding of them and how they relate to your conscious and subconscious
mind - i'll make more videos for that in the future but for now let's focus on developing this ability
to recall in detail, so the first and most basic practice is for us to go to bed with the intention
of remembering whatever experience we have in the night, and along with this intention we should also
intend to lay completely still when we wake up, now that doesn't mean you need to be too rigid
or anything and if you move around in your sleep a lot, don't worry about it, just try your best to be
still and try to gently and slowly wake up if you have an alarm set because you have a busy
day ahead of you simply try to intend to wake up before your alarm peacefully, don't worry if
it doesn't work but with a little faith you'll be surprised at how much you can actually wake up
before your alarm just by intending it, or perhaps saying an affirmation, you can even
say affirmations before bed such as "I WILL wake up peacefully without moving my physical body" and
just feel and anticipate that that's what you will do remember you may have an experience throughout
any time in the night, therefore you may also wake up during any time in the middle of the night
naturally - recalling dreams doesn't just need to be after your whole regular sleep cycle; we can have
experiences all throughout our sleep and you can wake up at any point in the middle of the night
here's a little tip: once you're lucid in a dream or a Astral projection experience you can set
the intention of impressing the experience on your mind in order to take the memory of the experience
back with you when you wake up; sort of like recording a video and your perceptions are the
camera like you're watching a movie, and if you're about to finish the experience and are going to
go back to your body just before you do go back to your body you can go through the entire experience
in your head before waking up, then when you wake up in your physical body replay all the scenes
again mentally, then of course get up and write it all down in your journal or record it as a voice
memo ~ of course this little tip is usually for people who are a bit more advanced or experienced
but it's still a good tip to keep in mind even if you are not having these experiences yet
now if you wake up and move, it's fine, don't panic or go into negative thinking simply lay back down
or stay still as soon as you remember your intent that you set before you slept - your intent to
recall your experiences - you will get better at this with practice your subconscious will learn
in time eventually you will find yourself, if you are consistent, waking up and not yet having moved
your physical body, ~ it can be quite a peculiar sensation when you wake up and haven't yet began
to move your physical body, you can sort of sense your astral-dream-connection to your consciousness...
and regardless, even if you move your physical body and stay still again the purpose of the mantra
i'm about to teach is to give you this massive boost in penetrating your subconscious memories
so don't be apprehensive at all just begin the mantra and retrospective exercise - the reason
why we should keep our physical body still is because once it moves the astral body is
sort of disturbed and the energy of it snaps back completely to physicality and the physical brain
and the mind just completely focuses on the world and everything we know about physical reality...
however if you're able to stay completely still upon awakening a big part of you
still stays within this non-physical connection where your consciousness
is still very much malleable and fresh in terms of having a strong link to your non-physical memories
just a kind of vague way to try to describe the benefits and significance of staying still
so with those little tips i just gave let me summarize and describe it more simply
combined with the mantra: so before sleeping intend to keep your physical body still when you wake up
with the purpose of remembering your dreams and once you wake up whether you managed to stay
still or you moved and stayed back still again begin the following mantra: it's called "RAOM GAOM"
that's ~ R-A-O-M G-A-O-M ~ it's essentially "OM" but with the "RA" at the start the first time and "GA"
the second time - you must do this mantra mentally; do not use your physical mouth to say it out loud
it's intended to be 100% mental, in your thoughts, as if you were doing it in a dream, so i'm going
to demonstrate it out loud but of course you do it in your head; so you can do it like this
RRRRAAAAAAAOOOOOMMMMMM GGAAAAOOOOMMMMMMM
you can do it more slowly and peacefully if you like like wrong
however way that makes you feel relaxed and focused and keep doing it once you wake up
be patient even if you get no memories or glimpses of any scenes whatsoever initially
just commit to doing the mantra when you wake up for at least a couple of minutes; I almost
guarantee if you do the mantra while combining it with the inner intention and struggle to
remember what you experienced during the night and crave and try to really remember
what you were doing the past 8, 9, 10 hours of your sleep, you will start to see certain scenes
in your inner vision and you'll start to remember, when you do start to remember certain things don't
stop your effort of doing the mantra, just continue, you'll notice one detail after another and as
you carry on more and more details and memories will reveal themselves and start flooding in, be
patient and try to slowly go through each scene in-depth you'll notice that each detail in each scene
will link to another memory, unlocking more of the story and narrative of what you were experiencing
remember every step you took, each part of a conversation, what emotions you were feeling,
what decisions you made, what clothes people were wearing, the color of the environment or objects
how dark or bright the sky was, what places you visited, what sounds you heard,
what thoughts you were thinking, how the experience started and how it ended - there's this tendency to
overlook the "boring" parts of dreams - but if you want to have strong
skills at remembering dreams then these minuscule details are the things you want to focus on
you'll be impressed that the level of detail these experiences can be from; studying the etchings on
a brick wall, to seeing tiny wrinkles on the palm of your hand, or just at how vast and enormous a
certain landscape can be, whether it be a forest, a jungle, out in the ocean, out in space or whatever,
so to conclude; intend to wake up without moving, then do the mantra while straining to remember,
you can even ask yourself mentally before you start mantralizing, "What did I dream?", then
replay all the scenes in your head, then move your physical body and write it all down in a journal
or use a voice recorder, and that's it really; in simple terms do the mantra every time you wake up: RAOM GAOM
that's the main message from this episode - and to further boost your memory you can also
every time before you go to bed and go to sleep review all of the recent experiences that you've
had; especially from the night before, the nights before that, and I would say the past three nights
at least: just review each one read it or listen to it however way you've recorded the dreams and you
will see that you know you're already exercising that muscle before you sleep and you'll see that
when you wake up it will be ready to recall these experiences again, and if you do become lucid or
have an OBE, you have the opportunity to remember very vividly by recalling experiences three times;
once while in the experience before you wake up, then after you wake up
then after you move your physical body, replaying scenes in your mind while out of body like this
is very powerful - so to talk very briefly on the meaning and significance behind the mantra; the
purpose of the mantra is to enter the subconscious in a direct way and to open up the mind to
the innate instinct to recall these memories and when mantralised when you just wake up is very
powerful because you're still in the bridge, the twilight between the physical and non-physical,
any time I have ever struggled to recall certain details of an experience or I have
a feeling that there was more to the experience than i initially remembered, i just mentally recite
the mantra patiently and the memories start to flood in spontaneously, let me tell you it
really works marvelously and i think a lot of you will have a high rate of success with it and will
come to love it too - let me know how you get on in the comments below i'd be interested to hear. The
mantra is compared to using dynamite to blow up mines, but in this practice of course it's to blow
up mental blockages in your subconscious to access banks of memory within, in a retrospective way, the
mantra is considered so powerful that it can also be used in deep prolonged meditation to remember
past lives, the RA part of the mantra is to do with illuminating the higher centers of our head
and brain and opening it up to the Akashic quality of consciousness where we can access memories
and knowledge, it can stimulate the third eye in this way, the pineal gland, helping us to receive
visuals and images, and the GA part of the mantra is similar instead it's more related to the throat
chakra and helping us to recall audio and other senses, and OM in itself is a profound mantra as
many of you may already know relating to the pure light and highest dimensions of nature or in other
words the highest dimensions of consciousness within ourselves, it's to do with our connection to
the Absolute, or infinite creative force, above and below... more specifically the sound "OOOO"
is related to the heart which is fundamental in stimulating in order to remember; you might think
the brain is more important to recall memories but actually the heart is where we center ourselves
enough to perceive these memories and the "MMMMM" part of OM is related to the Sacral Chakra
our primal, root self, and our intimate connection to our soul or spirit, so you might be able to
intuit a bit how if you combine RAOM and GAOM together can have really powerful effects
and regardless of the meaning and the vibration it can create - psychologically the benefits of doing a
mantra while recalling experiences keeps the mind busy so that our consciousness can review memories
without the mind becoming distracted i hope all of you give it a try and let me know how you get
on; i basically guarantee if you stick with it, your ability to recall dreams will improve tenfold, just
be sure that you're getting enough sleep, some people tell me that they've tried everything but
later on i find out that they're only sleeping five or six hours a night, you know in that case
i suggest you focus on just getting fuller and deeper and just better rested sleeps
so that your consciousness has the chance to recover from all the psychological things it
needs to process during sleep, so give it a try and just remember the more that your conscious mind
is connected to and involved in remembering these experiences, the more you'll form a relationship
with it and you'll start to see patterns and understand your subconscious self in
a more profound way with higher awareness, and through this awareness and connection
alone you'll raise your chances of being much more intimately involved in these experiences
directly, in other words you'll begin to have lucid dreams and Astral projection experiences
much more naturally ~ well thanks for listening everyone i always try to switch up each episode
accordingly to give you something different each week whether it be something more theoretical, more
challenging, guided meditation, or purely practical information like this one ~ if you're enjoying these
episodes be sure to give it a like, press the bell button so you know when there's a new episode, and
have a nice sleep and enjoy reclaiming your ability to review all of your dreams every morning!
